ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to critically read scientific papers and evaluate their validity, scientific method, etc. I also learned how to better communicate as a future scientist.
This class immensely improved my scientific literature skills, including how to critique papers and think of potentially better ways to conduct a study.

I learned how to read scientific literature quickly and efficiently, and discuss findings with my peers and the professors. I learned how to think critically about science and explore a lot of literature in a hot/quickly growing field. Learned a lot about genomics!
This class taught me how to critically read and evaluate scientific literature with an emphasis genetic techniques.
develope skills in dissecting data used in genetic analyses. Gained familiarity with different tools to analyze genetic associations with diseases and various statistical models used therein.
We learned how to interpret scientific literature surrounding the current state of human genomics. We also learned how to critique the papers and how to give brief informational presentations.
I learned how to read genetics scientific journals, how sequencing technology has changed over time, and how to critique published studies.
The class focused on proper scientific reading and analysis. I learned about many new techniques and data interpretation.

I learned many lessons that advanced my knowledge of The Human Genome and scientific research. I gained valuable insights about reading the primary literature, analyzing scientific experiments, and evaluating the results and conclusions.

I gained a deeper understanding of how to apply analytical skills to reading scientific papers, furthered my statistical intuitions, and learned so much about the human genome in this course. Im really grateful to have had the opportunity to apply genetic concepts that I learned at a foundational level in MCDB 202 to papers detailing pathology and novel methods for genetics like GWAS and long read sequencing.
I learned about DNA sequencing and the scientific techniques used to study the human genome.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: the papers were great and the discussion, when allowed to flow freely, was really fruitful. 
Weakness: sometimes the discussion was too centered around the figures or methods. We should have taken more time to discuss the overall social implications of the papers.

strengths:
great informative papers, engaged class, lots of opportunities to engage with professors/teaching staff
professors are excited about the material and love to talk about it

weaknesses:
some of the statistical methods employed in the papers are obtuse and hard to understand even with a stats background
wide range of difficulty in the papers and there is not a lot of time for the student presentations so although you learn how to be concise, i wish there was more time for us to unpack the papers in our presentation

The class was taught in a manner which focused entirely on student discussion, making it feel very organic and peer-led. At the same time, this semester it was taught by three instructors who were all very friendly and open to questions. They helped ensure the discussions stayed relevant and cleared any confusions.

Lack of clarity about how students would be evaluated in the course. This became stressful at the end of the class. 

Also, more time spent at the beginning of the course reviewing how to interpret genetics data (particularly sequence maps) and common statistical techniques would have facilitated greater student comprehension of papers reviewed throughout the course.

I thought the biggest strengths were the how up-to-date the papers were and the structure provided for discussions until everyone felt comfortable engaging in more open discussions. I can't think of any major weaknesses.
I think that spending more time discussing the statistics and how to interpret certain types of graphs would be helpful in gaining a better understanding of figures in the papers.
I liked the discussion structure and appreciated how both peers and professors were allowed to speak up.
The course was very well-organized. It explored various scientific topics that were very intriguing.

This course is phenomenal and I would recommend it to anyone majoring in MCDB. It has been one of my favorite classes at Yale and I truly have few suggestions on how the course would be improved because it was such a blast to participate in the class. The only thing that might improve the course is a short blurb from the instructor about mid-way through the semester on how individual students are doing or some sort of evaluation since there is no formal assessments to help us gauge our performance (and course correct if necessary) apart from class discussions.

I loved the chill environment  I feel like being less stressed about assignments helped everyone actually learn from the papers. I do wish though that we had like one intro class where we reviewed some of the concepts we discussed outside of the papers. There were a few things that kept coming up (ex. eQTLs) in our papers, but I was never really sure what they were and I felt embarrassed to ask.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. I think this class really stretched me.

Yes, it is a great class if you're at all interested in research, not only to learn about up-to-date genomics research, but to enhance your scientific literature skills. It will definitely help you think through your own experiments and writing more.

yes! no busywork, you just get to read and talk about cool papers with a very intelligent and accomplished teaching staff who are at the forefront of this field. highly recommend as an upper level MCDB elective that you will learn a lot from, without feeling overwhelmed or scared by workload/harsh grading that seems to be the MO in this department
Absolutely!
Great senior seminar for MCDB. Easy to engage with the course material without too much work. Not having exams/written assignments was a really nice perk.
Yes, given that they're interested in human genomics. It was a great was to engage with current research in the field and to develop skills for communicating or discussing scientific literature.
Yes, definitely take this course if you are interested in genetics or need an upper level MCDB course.
Yes absolutely! It is a class that teaches a lot of practical scientific skills in a fun and digest way. Also the professors and TA are all great!
Yes, I will certainly recommend this course to another student as it permits students to learn important lessons about the human genome and scientific research.

Yes (see above). This course is one of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale. I was intellectually challenged, felt freedom to explore topics I was genuinely intrigued by during the student papers selection week, and always felt supported by my peers and instructors when discussing the reading for the week.
Yes  the workload is VERY minimal, and the seminar vibe is a welcome change from big MCDB lectures.
